original_conversation.content: [yawn] So you teach marketing ethics at the university?
Mm, well, I wouldn't expect you to fully grasp the nuances, but yes, I'm the department chair. Most people think marketing ethics is just about not lying, which is, uh, adorably simplistic really.
What else is there to it then?

Oh dear. See, this is exactly why we need proper education on this topic. It's about stakeholder theory, deontological frameworks, virtue ethics applied to commercial speech—but I suppose those terms don't mean much to you, do they?
[bored] I know what deontological means.

Sure you do. Let me guess, you Googled it once? The real question is whether you understand how Kant's categorical imperative applies to targeted advertising algorithms, but, er, that's probably a bit advanced for this conversation.
You don't have to talk down to me.

Oh, I'm not talking down, I'm just... adjusting to your level. Look, most people in your position—what was it, middle management?—they don't really need to understand the theoretical foundations anyway.
I'm actually a senior director at a Fortune 500.
Hm. Senior director. Right. Well, that's... that's nice. Though honestly, corporate titles are so inflated these days, everyone's a director of something, aren't they?
We're implementing new ethical guidelines for our advertising.

Oh geez, another corporate ethics initiative. Let me guess—some consultant sold you a framework that's basically just "don't get sued," dressed up with fancy terminology? These things are usually, um, woefully inadequate.
We're working with Dr. Patricia Chen from Harvard.
[confidently] Patricia? Oh, bless. She's... she tries hard, really. Her work is very accessible, which I suppose is perfect for corporate audiences who need things simplified.
She said you were her student once.
Erhm, well, technically we were colleagues. Brief overlap at Harvard, though obviously I've, uh, significantly evolved beyond her rather pedestrian approach to utilitarian frameworks since then.
She mentioned you dropped out of her program.

[apologetic] That's not—okay, look, I chose to pursue more rigorous scholarship elsewhere. The Harvard program was, frankly, too focused on practical application rather than pure theory, which is really where the important work happens.
Right. So about those guidelines we need reviewed?

Mmm, sure, send them over, though I should warn you—most corporate ethics documents are basically philosophical disasters. But I'll, you know, try to translate my feedback into terms your team can actually comprehend.
